title: 110_hr3059
content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards under Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code, now require non-passenger automobiles to meet a minimum standard of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. The Secretary shall prescribe average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer for each model year, ensuring the maximum feasible level achievable. Separate standards may be set for different classes of passenger automobiles based on fuel economy-related attributes. The Secretary shall ensure that the average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer for model year 2022 and subsequent years is at least 35 miles per gallon. Additionally, there will be an alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, set at a minimum of 27.5 miles per gallon. The alternative minimum fuel economy standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is set at 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in the United States for that model year. The section allows manufacturers to comply with a less stringent fuel economy standard if they elect to do so during a transition period. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of the Act, with a transition period for passenger automobiles until a new standard is prescribed. The Fuel Conservation Education Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for drivers. The campaign will be accessible through various media channels and the Secretary will cover up to 50% of the costs, with the option to accept private funds. The Secretary of Transportation can accept private funds to supplement the campaign costs. Appropriations are authorized as needed for implementation.
